stemi.title: 2023 AHA/ACC Guidelines for Management of ST-Elevation MI

key_recommendations.text: Perform primary PCI within 90 minutes of first medical contact (door-to-balloon)
Administer aspirin 162-325mg as soon as possible, chewed
Administer P2Y12 inhibitor (ticagrelor or prasugrel preferred over clopidogrel) as loading dose
Anticoagulation with unfractionated heparin during PCI
Obtain 12-lead ECG within 10 minutes of ED arrival
If PCI cannot be performed within 120 min, administer fibrinolytic therapy within 30 min
key_recommendations.time_target: 30 minutes for fibrinolysis if no PCI

key_recommendations.text: Do NOT administer fibrinolytics if symptom onset >12 hours without ongoing ischemia

acute_ischemic_stroke.title: 2019 AHA/ASA Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke

key_recommendations.text: Non-contrast CT head within 25 minutes of ED arrival (door-to-CT)
IV alteplase (0.9 mg/kg, max 90mg) for eligible patients within 4.5 hours of symptom onset
Door-to-needle time ≤60 minutes for tPA administration
Mechanical thrombectomy for LVO within 24 hours if ASPECTS ≥6 and favorable perfusion imaging
BP management: permissive hypertension <220/120 if no tPA; <185/110 before and <180/105 after tPA
Do NOT give tPA if INR >1.7 or on DOAC with last dose <48h (unless specific reversal available)
Assess NIHSS score for stroke severity and guide treatment decisions

sepsis.title: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Campaign Guidelines

key_recommendations.text: Obtain blood cultures BEFORE initiating antibiotics (do not delay antibiotics >45 min for cultures)
key_recommendations.time_target: Before antibiotics, but don't delay >45 min

key_recommendations.text: Administer broad-spectrum IV antibiotics within 1 hour of sepsis recognition
Administer ≥30 mL/kg IV crystalloid within first 3 hours for sepsis-induced hypoperfusion
Use norepinephrine as first-line vasopressor for septic shock
Target MAP ≥65 mmHg in septic shock
Measure serum lactate; if elevated (>2 mmol/L), remeasure within 2-4 hours to guide resuscitation
Use dynamic measures (passive leg raise, fluid challenge) rather than static measures to guide fluid resuscitation
De-escalate antibiotics based on culture results and clinical improvement

hour_1_bundle: Rapid IV crystalloid 30 mL/kg for hypotension or lactate ≥4
Apply vasopressors for MAP <65 despite fluids
quality_metrics: Vasopressor within 1 hour if refractory hypotension
Lactate remeasured within 2-4 hours if initially elevated

dka.title: 2024 ADA Standards: Management of Diabetic Ketoacidosis

key_recommendations.text: IV normal saline 1-1.5 L/hr for first 1-2 hours, then 250-500 mL/hr adjusted by hydration status
Regular insulin infusion 0.1-0.14 U/kg/hr after potassium is confirmed ≥3.3 mEq/L
If serum K+ <3.3: hold insulin, replete K+ 20-40 mEq/hr until K+ ≥3.3
If K+ 3.3-5.3: give 20-30 mEq K+ in each liter of IV fluid
When glucose reaches 200 mg/dL: reduce insulin to 0.02-0.05 U/kg/hr, add D5 to maintain glucose 150-200
Bicarbonate only if pH <6.9 (give 100 mEq NaHCO3 in 400 mL with 20 mEq KCl)
Monitor BMP q2h, glucose q1h, ABG q2-4h until resolved
DKA resolution criteria: glucose <200, bicarb ≥15, pH >7.3, anion gap ≤12

quality_metrics: Insulin infusion started within 1 hour (if K+ ≥3.3)

chest_pain_heart_score.title: HEART Score for Chest Pain Risk Stratification

kawasaki.title: 2017 AHA Scientific Statement: Kawasaki Disease (2024 update)

plus_4_of_5: Oral mucosal changes (strawberry tongue, cracked lips)
diagnostic_criteria.incomplete_kawasaki: Fever ≥5 days + 2-3 criteria + elevated CRP/ESR → echocardiogram

key_recommendations.text: IVIG 2 g/kg as single infusion within 10 days of fever onset
High-dose aspirin 80-100 mg/kg/day divided q6h until afebrile 48-72 hours
Transition to low-dose aspirin 3-5 mg/kg/day after afebrile, continue 6-8 weeks
Echocardiogram at diagnosis, 2 weeks, and 6-8 weeks
If IVIG-resistant (fever >36h after first IVIG): repeat IVIG or consider IV methylprednisolone
Long-term follow-up with cardiology if coronary artery abnormalities develop

quality_metrics: IVIG within 10 days of fever onset

appendicitis.title: 2020 WSES Jerusalem Guidelines for Diagnosis and Treatment of Acute Appendicitis

key_recommendations.text: CT abdomen/pelvis is the gold standard for diagnosis in adults (sensitivity >95%)
Appendectomy (laparoscopic preferred) for uncomplicated appendicitis
Antibiotic-first strategy may be considered for uncomplicated appendicitis in selected patients
Preoperative antibiotics (single dose of cefoxitin or ceftriaxone + metronidazole)
Pregnancy test (beta-hCG) mandatory in women of childbearing age before CT

quality_metrics: Pregnancy test before CT in women of childbearing age
Surgical consultation within 60 minutes of diagnosis

pulmonary_embolism.title: 2019 ESC Guidelines on Acute Pulmonary Embolism

key_recommendations.text: Use validated clinical prediction rule (Wells or revised Geneva) for pre-test probability
D-dimer for PE-unlikely patients; CT-PA for PE-likely patients
Initiate therapeutic anticoagulation immediately when PE confirmed
Systemic thrombolysis for hemodynamically unstable (massive) PE
Consider thrombolysis for submassive PE with RV dysfunction and clinical deterioration
Risk stratify with sPESI score, troponin, BNP, and RV function assessment

quality_metrics: Appropriate imaging ordered (D-dimer vs CT-PA based on pre-test probability)
Therapeutic anticoagulation within 1 hour of diagnosis

low_back_pain.title: 2017 ACP Guidelines for Noninvasive Treatment of Low Back Pain
red_flags: Cauda equina syndrome (saddle anesthesia, bowel/bladder dysfunction)
History of cancer with new back pain
Significant trauma (or minor trauma if osteoporosis)

key_recommendations.text: Initial treatment: superficial heat, massage, acupuncture, or spinal manipulation (non-pharmacologic first)
If pharmacologic therapy needed: NSAIDs first-line, skeletal muscle relaxants second-line
Do NOT routinely obtain imaging for acute low back pain without red flags
Avoid opioids for acute low back pain; consider only if NSAIDs/muscle relaxants fail
For chronic LBP: exercise, multidisciplinary rehab, CBT, mindfulness

quality_metrics: No imaging ordered without red flags (for acute LBP <6 weeks)

antimicrobial_stewardship.title: Antimicrobial Stewardship Principles

key_recommendations.text: Obtain cultures before antibiotics whenever possible
Start empiric broad-spectrum coverage, de-escalate based on cultures within 48-72 hours
Adjust doses for renal and hepatic function
Use shortest effective duration (e.g., 5-7 days for uncomplicated pneumonia, not 10-14)
Check for drug allergies — true penicillin allergy is rare (<5% cross-react with cephalosporins)
Procalcitonin-guided discontinuation reduces unnecessary antibiotic duration

cross_reactivity.penicillin_cephalosporin: 1-2% true cross-reactivity; safe to use 3rd/4th gen cephalosporins in most PCN-allergic patients
cross_reactivity.sulfonamide_antibiotics_vs_nonantibiotic: No cross-reactivity between sulfa antibiotics and non-antibiotic sulfonamides

quality_metrics: Duration of therapy appropriate for indication
